elements.content: A series of novel metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been assembled from PbII and 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC-Cl4) by simply adding different alkali metal ions as templates. When only lead nitrate is used, a robust 3D open framework [Pb(BDC-Cl4)(MeOH)2] n (1) with pts topology can be obtained. Incorporating the lighter LiI or NaI ions into the above PbII/BDC-Cl4 system results in two unique isostructural 3D PbII–LiI and PbII–NaI heterometallic frameworks, {[PbLi2(BDC-Cl4)(μ2-OH)2](H2O)} n (2) and [PbNa2(BDC-Cl4)(μ2-OH)2] n (3), which are built from the combination of a 3D rod-packing PbII-carboxylate framework and a 3D NaI–BDC-Cl4 (or LiI–BDC-Cl4) network. When the heavier KI ion is applied, the similar reaction affords a 3D MOF [Pb2(BDC-Cl4)2(DMF)3] n (4), which represents the first pillar-layered PbII coordination network with a (3,5)-connected gra topology. The results illustrate the powerful effect of the alkali-metal templates in MOFs assemblies. The solid-state properties such as thermal stability and luminescence of 1–4 have also been studied.

When only lead nitrate is used, a robust 3D open framework [Pb(BDC-Cl4)(MeOH)2] n  (1) with pts topology can be obtained. Incorporating the lighter LiI or NaI ions into the above PbII/BDC-Cl4 system results in two unique isostructural 3D PbII-LiI and PbII-NaI heterometallic frameworks, {[PbLi2(BDC-Cl4)(μ2-OH)2](H2O)} n  (2) and [PbNa2(BDC-Cl4)(μ2-OH)2] n  (3), which are built from the combination of a 3D rod-packing PbII-carboxylate framework and a 3D NaI-BDC-Cl4 (or LiI-BDC-Cl4) network. When the heavier KI ion is applied, the similar reaction affords a 3D MOF [Pb2(BDC-Cl4)2(DMF)3] n  (4), which represents the first pillar-layered PbII coordination network with a (3,5)-connected gra topology. The results illustrate the powerful effect of the alkali-metal templates in MOFs assemblies. The solid-state properties such as thermal stability and luminescence of 1-4 have also been studied.

elements.content:
A series of novel 3D PbII coordination frameworks have been prepared through the alkali-metal-templated assembly of PbII salts with a rigid tetrachloroterephthalatic acid ligand.

Introduction

The past decade has witnessed the explosive development of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), because of not only their intriguing varieties of molecular architectures and topologies but also their potential applications in ferroelectrics, nonlinear optics, porous materials, and catalysis, etc. Considerable progress has been made on the theoretical forecast and practical approaches of controlled syntheses of MOFs. A current important approach to the rational assembly of crystalline frameworks is the use of templates (or structure-directing agents). Although the role of metal cations as templates for the assembly of supramolecular entities has received increasing attention, the issue of metal cations in the assembly of infinite coordination networks such as MOFs is not always easy. In fact, the metal ions as templates may accomplish various functions: (a) the final crystalline product is free of metal ions that however can influence the lattice formation; (b) metal ions are incorporated into the structures as guests that are not participating in coordination; (c) metal ions are involved in coordination that can usually produce interesting heterometallic coordination solids.
elements.clean_text:
A series of novel 3D PbII coordination frameworks have been prepared through the alkali-metal-templated assembly of PbII salts with a rigid tetrachloroterephthalatic acid ligand.

Introduction

The past decade has witnessed the explosive development of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), because of not only their intriguing varieties of molecular architectures and topologies but also their potential applications in ferroelectrics, nonlinear optics, porous materials, and catalysis, etc. Considerable progress has been made on the theoretical forecast and practical approaches of controlled syntheses of MOFs. A current important approach to the rational assembly of crystalline frameworks is the use of templates (or structure-directing agents). Although the role of metal cations as templates for the assembly of supramolecular entities has received increasing attention, the issue of metal cations in the assembly of infinite coordination networks such as MOFs is not always easy. In fact, the metal ions as templates may accomplish various functions: (a) the final crystalline product is free of metal ions that however can influence the lattice formation; (b) metal ions are incorporated into the structures as guests that are not participating in coordination; (c) metal ions are involved in coordination that can usually produce interesting heterometallic coordination solids.

elements.content: In contrast to transition-metal ions, alkaline cations can serve as favorable components in MOFs assembly because of their distinct coordinative admissibility, low polarizability, and unique affinity for various basic molecules (either strong or weak). For instance, the introduction of NaI/KI cations can be viewed as a viable heterometallic strategy to change the size and geometry of the clusters, to tune acidic pore surface and magnetic properties of MOFs. Moreover, the incorporation of alkali metal ions into the transition metal/carboxylate framework is interesting because the alkali cations are relevant as potential adsorption sites in the context of adsorbents for hydrogen. It is undoubtedly significant to understand the role of alkali-metal cations in directing the assemblies of MOFs with diverse and aesthetically pleased architectures.

elements.content: Recently, our interest has focused on the coordination assemblies based on polyhalogen-substituted benzenedicarboxylate derivatives, due to their unique linking modes and the potential ligand–metal reactions. In this regard, we have shown that solvent molecules play an essential role in the construction of MnII coordination frameworks with 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC-Cl4), and the resulting solvent-templated systems display diverse network structures. As a continuation of our research, we report herein the alkali-metal-templated assembly of a series of novel 3D PbII coordination frameworks (see Scheme ), that is, [Pb(BDC-Cl4)(MeOH)2] n (1), {[PbLi2(BDC-Cl4)(μ2-OH)2](H2O)} n (2), [PbNa2(BDC-Cl4)(μ2-OH)2] n (3), and [Pb2(BDC-Cl4)2(DMF)3] n (4). The thermal stability and luminescence property of 1–4 will also be presented.

elements.content: With the exception of the ligand H2BDC-Cl4, which was prepared according to the literature procedure, all reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. The Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra using KBr pellets were recorded on a Nicolet ESP 460 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a PE-2400II (Perkin-Elmer) analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2° min–1 and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Dupont thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C (heating rate of 10 °C min–1, nitrogen stream). Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured at room temperature on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Materials and Methods

With the exception of the ligand H2BDC-Cl4, which was prepared according to the literature procedure, all reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. The Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra using KBr pellets were recorded on a Nicolet ESP 460 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a PE-2400II (Perkin-Elmer) analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2° min-1 and a step size of 0.02° in 2θ. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Dupont thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C (heating rate of 10 °C min-1, nitrogen stream). Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured at room temperature on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer.

elements.content: In a 20 mL vial, Pb(NO3)2 (50.0 mg, 0.15 mmol) and H2BDC-Cl4 (45.9 mg, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (6.0 mL) and then diluted with methanol (12.0 mL). After stirring for ca. 30 min, the reaction mixture was filtered and left to stand at room temperature. After 5 days, colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvents in ca. 62% yield (53.6 mg, based on H2BDC-Cl4). elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of 1–4 were performed on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at the ambient temperature with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). In each case, a semiempirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS, and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. C-Bound hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions by using a riding model. O-Bound hydrogen atoms were localized by difference Fourier maps and refined in subsequent refinement cycles. Crystal and refinement data are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 ().
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction Determination and Refinement

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of 1-4 were performed on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at the ambient temperature with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). In each case, a semiempirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS, and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. C-Bound hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions by using a riding model. O-Bound hydrogen atoms were localized by difference Fourier maps and refined in subsequent refinement cycles. Crystal and refinement data are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 ().

As is well-known, metal ions play a crucial role in coordination assemblies, and in this work, our synthetic strategy uses alkali-metal ions as structure-directing agents to design and construct new coordination networks. Reaction of Pb(NO3)2 with H2BDC-Cl4 in a molar ratio of 1:1 in DMF–MeOH solution yields colorless block crystals of 1. Due to the poor solubility of NaNO3, KNO3, RbNO3, and CsNO3 in DMF–MeOH solution, alklai-metal salts including LiNO3, NaOAc·3H2O, KOAc, RbOAc, and CsOAc were used here. Upon adding LiNO3 or NaOAc·3H2O into the reaction system, colorless needle crystals of heterometallic MOFs 2 or 3 are obtained. When KOAc was used, colorless block crystals of 4 were isolated instead. Notably, even in the case of 4, where the KI ion is not incorporated into the resulting crystalline material, its presence is still necessary for the formation of the product. These experimental results indicate that LiI, NaI, and KI ions play different templating roles in the crystallization of these materials. Several efforts have been dedicated to synthesize the Pb–Rb and Pb–Cs systems; however, all these efforts were unsuccessful.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

As is well-known, metal ions play a crucial role in coordination assemblies, and in this work, our synthetic strategy uses alkali-metal ions as structure-directing agents to design and construct new coordination networks. Reaction of Pb(NO3)2 with H2BDC-Cl4 in a molar ratio of 1:1 in DMF-MeOH solution yields colorless block crystals of 1. Due to the poor solubility of NaNO3, KNO3, RbNO3, and CsNO3 in DMF-MeOH solution, alklai-metal salts including LiNO3, NaOAc⋅3H2O, KOAc, RbOAc, and CsOAc were used here. Upon adding LiNO3 or NaOAc⋅3H2O into the reaction system, colorless needle crystals of heterometallic MOFs 2 or 3 are obtained. When KOAc was used, colorless block crystals of 4 were isolated instead. Notably, even in the case of 4, where the KI ion is not incorporated into the resulting crystalline material, its presence is still necessary for the formation of the product. These experimental results indicate that LiI, NaI, and KI ions play different templating roles in the crystallization of these materials. Several efforts have been dedicated to synthesize the Pb-Rb and Pb-Cs systems; however, all these efforts were unsuccessful.

elements.content: Complexes 1–4 are stable to air and moisture and are insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, and acetonitrile. The results of microanalyses are consistent with their chemical formulas. The IR spectra of 1–4 display strong peaks in the range of 1576–1657 and 1332–1443 cm–1, which can be attributed to νasym(COO–) and νsym(COO–), respectively. The peaks for 1–3 appearing in the region of 3100–3500 cm–1 indicate the O–H stretching frequencies. Phase purity of 1–4 was confirmed by the experimental PXRD patterns, which are closely matched with the simulated patterns from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figure S1, ).

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that the structure of 1 is an extended 3D framework. As shown in Figure a, each PbII ion is holodirected and eight-coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms from four BDC-Cl4 ligands and two oxygen atoms from two terminal methanol ligands. The Pb–O bond distances are in the range of 2.559(3)–2.759(3) Å, which are in agreement with those reported for PbII coordination polymers with aromatic carboxylic acids. In each centrosymmetric BDC-Cl4, the rotation angle (φrot) between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate is 70.7(2)°, which is obviously lower than the corresponding values of the previously known complexes with BDC-Cl4 and other polychlorinated aromatic carboxylates. In 1, the BDC-Cl4 ligand is linked to four PbII ions with two carboxylate groups adopting the μ2-η2:η1-chelating/bridging mode (see Scheme a). To our knowledge, in all known complexes containing BDC-Cl4, the carboxylate group takes either μ1-η1:η0-monodentate or μ2-η1:η1-syn-syn-bridging/μ2-η2:η0-monodentate bridging mode. Due to such unique connectivity, the distorted PbO8 dodecahedra are interlinked to each other in an edge-sharing fashion to form an infinite 1D rod along the [001] axis (Figure b). These rods can be viewed as infinite rod-shaped secondary building units (SBUs), which are further extended into the final 3D open framework. Herein, each rod-shaped SBU is connected to four neighboring parallel rods through the BDC-Cl4 linkers, resulting in 1D rhombic channels (11.4 × 8.4 Å2, taking into account the van der Waals radii of the channel walls) along the c axis (see Figure c). Further analysis of the crystal packing reveals a sra type network topology considering each rod as a four-connected node. In another way of topological analysis, if each PbII center is regarded as a four-connected tetrahedral node and each BDC-Cl4 as a square building block, the resulting 3D structure can be described as a binodal four-connected pts net (Figure d). In addition, due to the existence of chlorine atoms and methanol molecules in the channels, the final 3D framework has very small voids of 96.3 Å3 (only 5.7% of the unit cell volume), as calculated by PLATON.

Crystal Structure of [Pb(BDC-Cl4)(MeOH)2] n  (1)

X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that the structure of 1 is an extended 3D framework. As shown in Figure a, each PbII ion is holodirected and eight-coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms from four BDC-Cl4 ligands and two oxygen atoms from two terminal methanol ligands. The Pb-O bond distances are in the range of 2.559(3)-2.759(3) Å, which are in agreement with those reported for PbII coordination polymers with aromatic carboxylic acids. In each centrosymmetric BDC-Cl4, the rotation angle (φrot) between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate is 70.7(2)°, which is obviously lower than the corresponding values of the previously known complexes with BDC-Cl4 and other polychlorinated aromatic carboxylates. In 1, the BDC-Cl4 ligand is linked to four PbII ions with two carboxylate groups adopting the μ2-η2:η1-chelating/bridging mode (see Scheme a). To our knowledge, in all known complexes containing BDC-Cl4, the carboxylate group takes either μ1-η1:η0-monodentate or μ2-η1:η1-syn-syn-bridging/μ2-η2:η0-monodentate bridging mode. Due to such unique connectivity, the distorted PbO8 dodecahedra are interlinked to each other in an edge-sharing fashion to form an infinite 1D rod along the [001] axis (Figure b). These rods can be viewed as infinite rod-shaped secondary building units (SBUs), which are further extended into the final 3D open framework. Herein, each rod-shaped SBU is connected to four neighboring parallel rods through the BDC-Cl4 linkers, resulting in 1D rhombic channels (11.4 × 8.4 Å2, taking into account the van der Waals radii of the channel walls) along the c axis (see Figure c). Further analysis of the crystal packing reveals a sra type network topology considering each rod as a four-connected node. In another way of topological analysis, if each PbII center is regarded as a four-connected tetrahedral node and each BDC-Cl4 as a square building block, the resulting 3D structure can be described as a binodal four-connected pts net (Figure d). In addition, due to the existence of chlorine atoms and methanol molecules in the channels, the final 3D framework has very small voids of 96.3 Å3 (only 5.7% of the unit cell volume), as calculated by PLATON.

elements.content: Views of 1: (a) The coordination environment of PbII and the binding mode of BDC-Cl4. Symmetry codes: (1) –x + 1, y, –z + 3/2; (2) –x + 1, –y, –z + 1; (3) x, –y, z + 1/2. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 2 and 3 are isostructural (Table ) and show a unique 3D heterometallic framework, which is built from the combination of a 3D PbII-carboxylate rod-packing framework and a 3D NaI–BDC-Cl4 (or LiI–BDC-Cl4) net. In this case, only the crystal structure of 3 is described in detail. As that in 1, each PbII ion is eight-coordinated (Figure a) to adopt a holodirected PbO8 geometry, which is however provided by two oxygen donors from two μ2-hydroxyl anions with the Pb–O distance of 2.731(4) Å and six oxygen atoms from four BDC-Cl4 ligands with the Pb–O distance in the range of 2.609(4)–2.628(3) Å. Within each BDC-Cl4 ligand, the φrot angle between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate is 85.7(2)°, which is higher than that of 1. Similar to that of 1, there are also PbO8 cores due to the identical coordination modes of carboxylate groups in 3, and thus, the PbO8 dodecahedra share edges with each other to afford infinite 1D rods along the [001] direction, which are further extended by BDC-Cl4 along the [100] and [010] directions to generate a 3D pts PbII–carboxylate coordination framework.

Crystal Structures of {[PbLi2(BDC-Cl4)(μ2-OH)2](H2O)} n  (2) and [PbNa2(BDC-Cl4)(μ2-OH)2] n  (3)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 2 and 3 are isostructural (Table ) and show a unique 3D heterometallic framework, which is built from the combination of a 3D PbII-carboxylate rod-packing framework and a 3D NaI-BDC-Cl4 (or LiI-BDC-Cl4) net. In this case, only the crystal structure of 3 is described in detail. As that in 1, each PbII ion is eight-coordinated (Figure a) to adopt a holodirected PbO8 geometry, which is however provided by two oxygen donors from two μ2-hydroxyl anions with the Pb-O distance of 2.731(4) Å and six oxygen atoms from four BDC-Cl4 ligands with the Pb-O distance in the range of 2.609(4)-2.628(3) Å. Within each BDC-Cl4 ligand, the φrot angle between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate is 85.7(2)°, which is higher than that of 1. Similar to that of 1, there are also PbO8 cores due to the identical coordination modes of carboxylate groups in 3, and thus, the PbO8 dodecahedra share edges with each other to afford infinite 1D rods along the [001] direction, which are further extended by BDC-Cl4 along the [100] and [010] directions to generate a 3D pts PbII-carboxylate coordination framework.

elements.content: The coordination environment around NaI is shown in Figure b. Each NaI center is surrounded by three chlorine bridges (Cl1, Cl2, and Cl3) from three BDC-Cl4 ligands and one oxygen donor (O3) from the μ2-hydroxyl anion. The Na–O distance [3.017(2) Å] is similar to that of 2.996 Å observed in [Nd2Na8(OCH2CH2NMe2)12(OH)2]. The Na1–Cl1#1 distance [2.536(2) Å] is slightly longer than that of Na1–Cl1 [2.402(2) Å] but significantly shorter than that of Na1–Cl2 [3.107(2) Å]. It is noteworthy that the Cl2 atom is weakly coordinated with the NaI center, where the Na1–Cl2 distance is longer than that in the NaCl crystal lattice [2.8199(7) Å] but comparable to those found in the bridging chlorine compound [Nd12(OtAm)26(HOtAm)2Cl11Na]·(OEt2)2 (HOtAm = tert-amyl alcohol), with the Na–Cl distances in the range of 3.222(11)–3.339(11) Å. Considering this obvious elongation of Na1–Cl2, the NaI ion may be best described as pseudotetracoordinate to take a distorted tetrahedron geometry NaCl3O, in which the average angles are 110.5(1)° for Cl–Na–Cl and 109.7(1)° for Cl–Na–O, deviating substantially from 109.5° for an idea tetrahedron. The two C 2 axis-related NaI ions (Na1 and Na1#1) are linked by two chlorine atoms (Cl1 and Cl1#1) to form a Na2Cl2 rectangle unit with the Na···Na distance of 3.458 Å (Figure b), which is significantly shorter than that in NaCl (3.988 Å). Each dinuclear unit is further connected by four BDC-Cl4 ligands to afford a 3D framework. If we consider both the connectivity of PbII/NaI ions, each NaI center acts as a four-connected node connecting three BDC-Cl4 ligands and one PbII ion and each PbII center acts as a six-connected node linking four BDC-Cl4 ligands and two NaI ions. As a consequence, each BDC-Cl4 ligand serves as a 10-connected node to link four PbII ions and six NaI ions. So the overall 3D structure can be describes as a complicated three-nodal (4,6,10)-connected network (Figure c) with Schläfli symbol of (3.43.52)2(32.414.516.68.74.8)(32.45.56.62).

elements.content: Complex 4 also shows an extended 3D coordination network. The fundamental building unit consists of two crystallographically unique PbII centers (Pb1 and Pb2), two BDC-Cl4 ligands with different coordination modes, and three terminal DMF molecules (Figure a). Pb1 is hemidirected and five-coordinated by oxygen atoms (PbO5) from three different BDC-Cl4 anions and two DMF molecules. Pb2 is holodirected and eight-coordinated by oxygen atoms (PbO8) from one DMF and four different BDC-Cl4 ligands. The Pb–Ocarboxylate and Pb–ODMF lengths are in the range of 2.317(4)–2.754(4) and 2.473(3)–2.601(2) Å, respectively. The BDC-Cl4 ligands show two types of coordination modes, that is, BDC-Cl4 I is μ4-bridging with each carboxylate in a μ2-η2:η1-chelating/bridging mode (Scheme a) and BDC-Cl4 II is μ3-bridging with one carboxylate in a μ1-η1:η1-chelating mode and the other in a μ2-η1:η1-syn-anti-bridging fashion (Scheme d). The rotation angles (φrot) between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate groups vary from 80.3(3) to 88.7(3)°. The PbO5 polyhedron of Pb1 shares one edge with the PbO8 polyhedron of Pb2 via two carboxylate oxygen atoms of BDC-Cl4 I, forming the unsymmetric Pb2O11 unit with a Pb···Pb separation of 3.959(3) Å. The adjacent such dinuclear units are connected alternatively via BDC-Cl4 II, forming an 1D infinite Pb–O–C chain along [101] (Figure b). Such Pb–O–C chains, as infinite rod-shaped SBUs, are further extended by BDC-Cl4 I and BDC-Cl4 II to form a 3D network (Figure c).

Crystal Structure of [Pb2(BDC-Cl4)2(DMF)3] n  (4)

Complex 4 also shows an extended 3D coordination network. The fundamental building unit consists of two crystallographically unique PbII centers (Pb1 and Pb2), two BDC-Cl4 ligands with different coordination modes, and three terminal DMF molecules (Figure a). Pb1 is hemidirected and five-coordinated by oxygen atoms (PbO5) from three different BDC-Cl4 anions and two DMF molecules. Pb2 is holodirected and eight-coordinated by oxygen atoms (PbO8) from one DMF and four different BDC-Cl4 ligands. The Pb-Ocarboxylate and Pb-ODMF lengths are in the range of 2.317(4)-2.754(4) and 2.473(3)-2.601(2) Å, respectively. The BDC-Cl4 ligands show two types of coordination modes, that is, BDC-Cl4 I is μ4-bridging with each carboxylate in a μ2-η2:η1-chelating/bridging mode (Scheme a) and BDC-Cl4 II is μ3-bridging with one carboxylate in a μ1-η1:η1-chelating mode and the other in a μ2-η1:η1-syn-anti-bridging fashion (Scheme d). The rotation angles (φrot) between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate groups vary from 80.3(3) to 88.7(3)°. The PbO5 polyhedron of Pb1 shares one edge with the PbO8 polyhedron of Pb2 via two carboxylate oxygen atoms of BDC-Cl4 I, forming the unsymmetric Pb2O11 unit with a Pb⋅⋅⋅Pb separation of 3.959(3) Å. The adjacent such dinuclear units are connected alternatively via BDC-Cl4 II, forming an 1D infinite Pb-O-C chain along [101] (Figure b). Such Pb-O-C chains, as infinite rod-shaped SBUs, are further extended by BDC-Cl4 I and BDC-Cl4 II to form a 3D network (Figure c).

elements.content: From the topological point of view, each dinuclear PbII unit is considered as a trigonal bipyramidal five-connected node, and the BDC-Cl4 I and BDC-Cl4 II ligands are two- and three-connected, respectively. As shown in Figure d, a D layer is formed by connecting the BDC-Cl4 II ligands and the neighboring dinuclear units, with the interlayer distance of 10.223(6) Å. Such layers are then bridged via the two-connecting BDC-Cl4 I tectons between the five-connecting dinuclear PbII units, generating a (3,5)-connected gra net (Figure e) with the point symbol of (63)(69.8). In contrast to the extensive investigations on (3,4)- and (3,6)-connected nets, those on (3,5)-connected networks are quite limited. In fact, only several MOFs with the gra net have been reported, where the metal centers normally act as the five-connected nodes. Further, the (3,5)-connected gra nets based on the dinuclear metal–carboxylate units are even rarer and only found for metal ions such as ZnII, CuII, NiII, AgI, and CdII, probably owing to that such units prefer to serve as four- or six-connected nodes. It should be emphasized that 4 represents the first PbII coordination framework with gra topology and, in contrast to other (3,5)-connected nets, shows an open noninterpenetrating structure, where the chlorine groups prevent the occurrence of interpenetration. The 3D lattice of 4 has no solvent-accessible area, as calculated by the PLATON package.

elements.content: By just introducing different alkali-metal ions (LiI, NaI, or KI) under similar reaction conditions, a series of PbII–BDC-Cl4 systems can be prepared, and their structural diversity (see Table for structural features of 1–4) can be attributed to the template effect of alkali-metal ions. When only PbII ion is used, the resulting complex 1 shows a 3D rod-shaped open framework with four-connected pts topology. However, the nitrogen gas adsorption studies carried out on this sample did not show the presence of a porous structure. Interestingly, upon the incorporation of LiI or NaI ions, the isostructural crystalline products 2 and 3 feature the unprecedented 3D heterometallic frameworks with complicated trinodal topology. The overall structure is built from the combination of a 3D PbII–carboxylate rod-packing net and a 3D LiI/NaI–BDC-Cl4 net. Similar to the LiI cation that can form various chloride complex ions, the NaI cation is also involved in coordination with the chlorine atoms of BDC-Cl4 ligand. Evidently, the addition of LiI or NaI ions does significantly affect the resulting network structures via not only metal–carboxylate coordination but also metal–chlorocarbon interactions. Moreover, if the LiI or NaI ions are regarded as the guest cations, the PbII–carboxylate host frameworks of 2 or 3 are the same as that of 1. When potassium acetate is applied, another unique 3D MOF 4 is formed, which presents the first (3,5)-connected network of PbII MOF with pillar-layered gra topology. In contrast to 2 and 3, though the KI ion is not involved in the final crystalline product, which can be assigned to its large size (2 Å3 for LiI, 3 Å3 for NaI, and 10 Å3 for KI), it plays an essential role in the formation of 4. In addition, the PbII MOFs 1 and 4 crystallize in different space groups with dissimilar coordination modes of the carboxylate groups and show distinct topologies of the final coordination networks. On the basis of the structural features of 1–4, it could be concluded that the addition of alkali-metal cations to the PbII–BDC-Cl4 system apparently affects the connectivity of the BDC-Cl4 tecton (see Table ). Interestingly, a recent similar example reports a series of lanthanide-alkali coordination polymers with isonicotinate (INA) ligand. In this system, structures with remarkably different connectivities are formed when LiI, NaI, and KI were introduced. Due to the size effect of the alkali metal ions, Ln–Li (or Na) complexes are isostructural chiral 3D coordination polymers using the LiI and NaI ions as precursors, while achiral 3D pillared Ln–K coordination polymer was obtained when the KI ion was introduced.
elements.clean_text:
Template Effect of Alkali-Metal Ions

By just introducing different alkali-metal ions (LiI, NaI, or KI) under similar reaction conditions, a series of PbII-BDC-Cl4 systems can be prepared, and their structural diversity (see Table  for structural features of 1-4) can be attributed to the template effect of alkali-metal ions. When only PbII ion is used, the resulting complex 1 shows a 3D rod-shaped open framework with four-connected pts topology. However, the nitrogen gas adsorption studies carried out on this sample did not show the presence of a porous structure. Interestingly, upon the incorporation of LiI or NaI ions, the isostructural crystalline products 2 and 3 feature the unprecedented 3D heterometallic frameworks with complicated trinodal topology. The overall structure is built from the combination of a 3D PbII-carboxylate rod-packing net and a 3D LiI/NaI-BDC-Cl4 net. Similar to the LiI cation that can form various chloride complex ions, the NaI cation is also involved in coordination with the chlorine atoms of BDC-Cl4 ligand. Evidently, the addition of LiI or NaI ions does significantly affect the resulting network structures via not only metal-carboxylate coordination but also metal-chlorocarbon interactions. Moreover, if the LiI or NaI ions are regarded as the guest cations, the PbII-carboxylate host frameworks of 2 or 3 are the same as that of 1. When potassium acetate is applied, another unique 3D MOF 4 is formed, which presents the first (3,5)-connected network of PbII MOF with pillar-layered gra topology. In contrast to 2 and 3, though the KI ion is not involved in the final crystalline product, which can be assigned to its large size (2 Å3 for LiI, 3 Å3 for NaI, and 10 Å3 for KI), it plays an essential role in the formation of 4. In addition, the PbII MOFs 1 and 4 crystallize in different space groups with dissimilar coordination modes of the carboxylate groups and show distinct topologies of the final coordination networks. On the basis of the structural features of 1-4, it could be concluded that the addition of alkali-metal cations to the PbII-BDC-Cl4 system apparently affects the connectivity of the BDC-Cl4 tecton (see Table ). Interestingly, a recent similar example reports a series of lanthanide-alkali coordination polymers with isonicotinate (INA) ligand. In this system, structures with remarkably different connectivities are formed when LiI, NaI, and KI were introduced. Due to the size effect of the alkali metal ions, Ln-Li (or Na) complexes are isostructural chiral 3D coordination polymers using the LiI and NaI ions as precursors, while achiral 3D pillared Ln-K coordination polymer was obtained when the KI ion was introduced.

elements.content: It should be noted that halocarbons RX, where R is an alkyl or aryl group and X is a halogen atom, represent a peculiar type of ligand in coordination chemistry. They are very weak bases, and consequently, the coordination to transition-metal ions is labile and the RX–M bonds will be easily broken by nucleophilic attack. Recent research results have shown that alkali-metal ions are favorable and can bond to halogen atoms strongly. However, the fully characterized examples for coordination species with halocarbon ligands and alkali metals are mainly restricted to fluorine-based ligands. At this stage, the coordination assembly involving metal–chlorocarbon is very rare, and the 3D LiI–BDC-Cl4 and NaI–BDC-Cl4 networks of 2 and 3 represent the first examples for MOFs with such a unique feature. Without a doubt, the current results reveal that it is an effective synthetic strategy to construct new MOFs materials using the perhalogenated ligands upon reaction with alkali-metal ions.

The thermal stability of these crystalline materials was investigated by TG analysis technique ( Figure S2). For 1, the coordinated methanol molecules were removed between 25 and 130 °C (found, 10.9%; calcd, 11.1%). With that, almost no weight loss was observed until heating to 240 °C, where the residual framework began to decompose. In the case of 2, the TG curve indicates that the first weight loss corresponds to the elimination of lattice water molecules (found, 3.6%; calcd, 3.1%), and the guest-free framework can be maintained up to about 255 °C. 3 shows a higher thermal stability with the mass remaining largely unchanged until the decomposition onset temperature of ca. 280 °C. Critical weight losses in the temperature of 280–450 °C indicate the pyrolysis of organic components. For 4, with the increase of temperature, it is thermally stable to 170 °C, and the first weight loss corresponds to the loss of DMF ligands occurring in the range of ca. 170–230 °C (found, 17.2%; calcd, 17.7%). The remaining framework is decomposed with two consecutive weight losses above 230 °C and not ending at 800 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

The thermal stability of these crystalline materials was investigated by TG analysis technique ( Figure S2). For 1, the coordinated methanol molecules were removed between 25 and 130 °C (found, 10.9%; calcd, 11.1%). With that, almost no weight loss was observed until heating to 240 °C, where the residual framework began to decompose. In the case of 2, the TG curve indicates that the first weight loss corresponds to the elimination of lattice water molecules (found, 3.6%; calcd, 3.1%), and the guest-free framework can be maintained up to about 255 °C. 3 shows a higher thermal stability with the mass remaining largely unchanged until the decomposition onset temperature of ca. 280 °C. Critical weight losses in the temperature of 280-450 °C indicate the pyrolysis of organic components. For 4, with the increase of temperature, it is thermally stable to 170 °C, and the first weight loss corresponds to the loss of DMF ligands occurring in the range of ca. 170-230 °C (found, 17.2%; calcd, 17.7%). The remaining framework is decomposed with two consecutive weight losses above 230 °C and not ending at 800 °C.

elements.content: Due to the excellent luminescent properties of d10 PbII complexes, the photoluminescence of 1–4 as well as the organic ligand H2BDC-Cl4 in the solid state were investigated at room temperature. Upon excitation at 337 nm, the strongest emission peak for free ligand appears at 474 nm, corresponding to the n →π* transitions. For 1–4, excitation of the microcrystalline samples at 336 nm (see Figure inset) leads to the generation of intense fluorescent emissions (Figure ), with similar maximum peaks observed in the blue region (1, 477 nm; 2, 477 nm; 3, 477 nm; and 4, 479 nm), which may be attributed to the ligand-centered transitions. In addition, the weaker shoulder peaks of the emission spectra around 510 nm can probably be assigned to the intraligand transition because a similar peak at about 512 nm also appears for the ligand H2BDC-Cl4. Furthermore, the emission intensity of complexes 1–4 are significantly weaker than that of the free ligand, which is likely related to their complicated structures as well as the decay effect of high-energy C–H and/or O–H oscillators from lattice and coordinated solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Due to the excellent luminescent properties of d10 PbII complexes, the photoluminescence of 1-4 as well as the organic ligand H2BDC-Cl4 in the solid state were investigated at room temperature. Upon excitation at 337 nm, the strongest emission peak for free ligand appears at 474 nm, corresponding to the n →π* transitions. For 1-4, excitation of the microcrystalline samples at 336 nm (see Figure  inset) leads to the generation of intense fluorescent emissions (Figure ), with similar maximum peaks observed in the blue region (1, 477 nm; 2, 477 nm; 3, 477 nm; and 4, 479 nm), which may be attributed to the ligand-centered transitions. In addition, the weaker shoulder peaks of the emission spectra around 510 nm can probably be assigned to the intraligand transition because a similar peak at about 512 nm also appears for the ligand H2BDC-Cl4. Furthermore, the emission intensity of complexes 1-4 are significantly weaker than that of the free ligand, which is likely related to their complicated structures as well as the decay effect of high-energy C-H and/or O-H oscillators from lattice and coordinated solvent molecules.

elements.content: In summary, we have demonstrated the alkali-metal-templated syntheses of a series of novel 3D PbII MOFs with a perchlorinated benzenedicarboxylate tecton BDC-Cl4 that show interesting structural diversity, regardless of whether the alkali-metal ions are included in the final crystalline products. The introduction of different alkali-metal ions plays an essential role in the coordination mode of carboxylate, the connectivity of ligand, and the overall topological networks of the framework materials. This work also provides new knowledge on metal–chlorocarbon coordination chemistry, as found in the unprecedented LiI–BDC-Cl4 and NaI–BDC-Cl4 networks in 2 and 3. Accordingly, our present findings will enrich the crystal engineering strategies and offer the possibility of controlling preparation of such desired network-based solids. Further studies are ongoing to construct more novel inorganic–organic hybrid materials using various halogenated benzenedicarboxylate ligands and alkali-metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have demonstrated the alkali-metal-templated syntheses of a series of novel 3D PbII MOFs with a perchlorinated benzenedicarboxylate tecton BDC-Cl4 that show interesting structural diversity, regardless of whether the alkali-metal ions are included in the final crystalline products. The introduction of different alkali-metal ions plays an essential role in the coordination mode of carboxylate, the connectivity of ligand, and the overall topological networks of the framework materials. This work also provides new knowledge on metal-chlorocarbon coordination chemistry, as found in the unprecedented LiI-BDC-Cl4 and NaI-BDC-Cl4 networks in 2 and 3. Accordingly, our present findings will enrich the crystal engineering strategies and offer the possibility of controlling preparation of such desired network-based solids. Further studies are ongoing to construct more novel inorganic-organic hybrid materials using various halogenated benzenedicarboxylate ligands and alkali-metal ions.

In a 20 mL vial, Pb(NO3)2 (50.0 mg, 0.15 mmol) and H2BDC-Cl4 (45.9 mg, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (6.0 mL) and then diluted with methanol (12.0 mL). After stirring for ca. 30 min, the reaction mixture was filtered and left to stand at room temperature. After 5 days, colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvents in ca. 62% yield (53.6 mg, based on H2BDC-Cl4). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C10H8Cl4O6Pb: C, 20.95; H, 1.41. Found: C, 20.83; H, 1.41. IR (cm–1): 3413 bs, 2934 m, 1657 s, 1588 vs, 1443 s, 1366 vs, 1269 m, 1127 m, 1020 w, 974 s, 797 m, 751 s, 683 m, 594 s.

The same synthetic procedure as that for 1 was used except that LiNO3 (31.2 mg, 0.45 mmol) was added, affording colorless needle crystals in ca. 47% yield (40.8 mg, on the basis of H2BDC-Cl4). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C8H4Cl4Li2O7Pb: C, 16.71; H, 0.70. Found: C, 16.65; H, 0.70. The same synthetic procedure as that for 2 was used except that LiNO3 was replaced by NaOAc·3H2O (61.6 mg, 0.45 mmol), affording colorless needle crystals in ca. 42% yield (37.3 mg, on the basis of H2BDC-Cl4). The thermal stability of these crystalline materials was investigated by TG analysis technique ( Figure S2). For 4, with the increase of temperature, it is thermally stable to 170 °C, and the first weight loss corresponds to the loss of DMF ligands occurring in the range of ca. 170–230 °C (found, 17.2%; calcd, 17.7%). The remaining framework is decomposed with two consecutive weight losses above 230 °C and not ending at 800 °C.

Luminescent Properties

Due to the excellent luminescent properties of d10 PbII complexes, the photoluminescence of 1–4 as well as the organic ligand H2BDC-Cl4 in the solid state were investigated at room temperature. Upon excitation at 337 nm, the strongest emission peak for free ligand appears at 474 nm, corresponding to the n →π* transitions. Furthermore, the emission intensity of complexes 1–4 are significantly weaker than that of the free ligand, which is likely related to their complicated structures as well as the decay effect of high-energy C–H and/or O–H oscillators from lattice and coordinated solvent molecules.
